nodes.name: Execute Workflow Trigger
nodes.notes:
üì• TRIGGER: This workflow is called by the main Ingestion workflow.

Expected input data:
- video_id, video_title, video_url
- niche, target_audience, tone
- tweet_count, linkedin_count
- transcript

nodes.name: Extract Ideas (GLM-4.6)
nodes.notes:
üîß CONFIGURATION REQUIRED:

1. Create Header Auth credential named 'GLM-4 API'
2. Header Name: Authorization
3. Header Value: Bearer YOUR_Z_AI_API_KEY

Endpoint: Z.AI Coding Plan
Model: GLM-4.6

nodes.name: Extract Ideas (Kimi-K2)
nodes.notes:
üîß CONFIGURATION REQUIRED:

1. Create Header Auth credential named 'Groq API'
2. Header Name: Authorization
3. Header Value: Bearer YOUR_GROQ_API_KEY

Get key from: console.groq.com
Model: Moonshot Kimi-K2

nodes.name: Merge & Parse Ideas
nodes.notes:
üìã AUTO-CONFIGURED:

This node merges responses from both AI providers and parses the JSON.

No configuration needed - just verify output after testing.

nodes.name: Store Ideas
nodes.notes:
üîß CONFIGURATION REQUIRED:

1. Select Google Sheets OAuth2 credential
2. Select 'Content Repurposing Engine' spreadsheet
3. Select 'Ideas_Extracted' sheet

Required columns in sheet:
status | idea_id | video_id | glm_ideas | kimi_ideas | extracted_at

nodes.name: Return Output
nodes.notes:
üì§ OUTPUT:

Returns extracted ideas to the calling workflow.

Data includes:
- ideas_glm: Ideas extracted by GLM-4.6
- ideas_kimi: Ideas extracted by Kimi-K2
- All original metadata

nodes.name: Extract Ideas (groq/compound)
nodes.notes:
üîß CONFIGURATION REQUIRED:

1. Create Header Auth credential named 'Groq API'
2. Header Name: Authorization
3. Header Value: Bearer YOUR_GROQ_API_KEY

Get key from: console.groq.com
Model: Moonshot Kimi-K2

json.video_title: How to Automate Any Business With AI in 3 Steps (Beginner's Guide)
json.transcript:
Transcript
[00:00] So over the past two and a half years,
[00:01] my agency, Morningside AI, has been on
[00:02] the front lines of implementing AI for
[00:04] some of the world's biggest brands. And
[00:05] I can tell you that the difference
[00:06] between the 5% of companies who are
[00:08] seeing a massive ROI on AI and the 95%
[00:11] who are failing right now is simple, and
[00:13] that's that they start with a process
[00:15] and not the technology. Most businesses
[00:17] get this backwards. They get all hyped
[00:18] about a new tool and they dive straight
[00:20] into the development and ultimately
[00:22] fail. And from this, companies are
[00:24] learning that the initial shine of AI is
[00:25] gone now. And this stuff takes real
[00:27] human skill to get right. And even
[00:29] OpenAI has kind of just admitted this
[00:31] openly by launching their own consulting
[00:33] team. So whether you're a business owner
[00:34] who wants to join this 5% of winners or
[00:36] an entrepreneur who wants to serve the
[00:38] 95% of companies who are failing and
[00:39] need help, then this video is for you
[00:41] because I'm about to open source the
[00:43] entire start to finish framework that we
[00:44] use at Morningside AI for automating any
[00:46] business with AI. And at the end, I'll
[00:48] give you a full guide so that you can go
[00:49] and apply this stuff yourself. So if you
[00:51] are new to the channel, my name is Liam
[00:52] Mley and for the past 2 and a half
[00:53] years, I've been helping businesses and
[00:55] individuals to use AI to get ahead. And
[00:57] I do this because our vision at
[00:58] Morningside is to ensure that the games
[01:00] of the AI revolution aren't just for the
[01:02] big guys. And that's why I share our
[01:03] learnings here on this channel to give
[01:05] businesses the tools to survive and win
[01:07] in this AI revolution.
[01:10] So, here's the deal. This is a reality
[01:12] check for almost every single business
[01:13] out there right now. But what they
[01:14] ultimately want is growth, which
[01:16] requires order. Most companies are a
[01:18] complete mess. Their data is scattered.
[01:20] Their processes are a mix of how we've
[01:21] always done it and a dozen different
[01:23] apps or tools that don't talk to each
[01:25] other. And now according to studies,
[01:26] most of their employees are secretly
[01:28] using a bunch of AI tools to get parts
[01:30] of their work done without them telling
[01:32] the company. And that's creating huge
[01:33] risks of data leaks etc. So it's
[01:35] organized chaos at best. And most
[01:37] business owners are just trying to keep
[01:38] the wheels from falling off. And so now
[01:40] when you take this chaotic system and
[01:42] you try to just plug in the most
[01:44] powerful technology on the planet right
[01:45] now, what do you think happens? Right?
[01:47] It's going to fail and it's going to
[01:48] fail pretty miserably. And you don't
[01:49] actually have to take my word for it on
[01:50] that. The numbers are pretty brutal. MIT
[01:53] has published a study recently showing
[01:54] that 95% of AI initiatives and
[01:56] businesses fail to deliver a return on
[01:58] investment. Let me say that again. The
[02:00] vast majority of businesses that try to
[02:02] implement AI are getting zero value from
[02:04] it. This is in enterprise to be fair, so
[02:06] it's sort of bigger businesses, but it's
[02:07] still an interesting point. But that's
[02:08] not because this technology is useless.
[02:10] That's because these companies are
[02:12] trying to copy what everyone else is
[02:13] doing and they're failing miserably
[02:14] because of it. Instead of taking the
[02:16] time to do the real exploratory work to
[02:18] figure out where AI can fit their
[02:19] business best, they are just looking for
[02:21] the headlines and looking for YouTube
[02:22] videos and and stealing from other
[02:24] people, rather than doing the ground
[02:25] work to find where AI best fits their
[02:27] organization. And often when they try to
[02:29] do it themselves, they are actually
[02:30] clueless to what it really takes to see
[02:32] AI adoption within teams of emotional
[02:34] and fearful humans. There are human
[02:36] barriers to adoption and actually seeing
[02:37] an ROI that many companies are just not
[02:39] aware of right now. So what the 5% who
[02:41] are actually seeing an ROI are doing is
[02:42] they're starting from square one and
[02:44] taking a comprehensive and holistic
[02:46] approach to AI opportunity
[02:47] identification and then development
[02:49] within the company in order to find what
[02:51] we call like layups or or quick wins
[02:53] with AI that can really drive immediate
[02:55] ROI from them. And so the reason the
[02:56] majority of these companies are not
[02:58] seeing an ROI is because they are trying
[02:59] to go for what the neighbor said that
[03:01] they were doing and and not seeing these
[03:02] golden nuggets laying right in front of
[03:04] them, which are the quick wins, the
[03:05] quick ROI projects that can implement AI
[03:08] quickly and allow them to see a return
[03:09] on their investment. And I can say with
[03:10] complete confidence from the client work
[03:12] we do at Morningside, there are always
[03:13] these quick wins lying around that
[03:15] companies are just not aware of and how
[03:16] AI can plug into those and really solve
[03:18] a bottleneck for them that's been
[03:19] troubling them for a while. Now, if
[03:20] you're a business owner watching this,
[03:21] these stats should be a massive wakeup
[03:22] call. It means that almost all of your
[03:24] competitors are trying to use AI and
[03:26] they're failing and they're wasting
[03:27] money, they're wasting time, they're
[03:29] getting nowhere. So, this gives you a
[03:30] huge advantage because if you can be one
[03:32] of the small percentage who gets this
[03:34] right by properly auditing your business
[03:35] and following the exact process that I'm
[03:37] about to lay out for you, you'll
[03:38] dominate your industry for years to come
[03:40] using these advantages. And if you're an
[03:41] aspiring entrepreneur, that same stat
[03:43] should sound to you like the biggest
[03:44] dinner bell you have ever heard because
[03:46] it means that there are millions of
[03:47] businesses out there who are hungry for
[03:49] the most powerful technology on the
[03:50] planet right now. And they have no idea
[03:52] how to use it or get an ROI from it. So
[03:54] this is an enormous and untapped market
[03:56] and your job is to figure out how to
[03:58] bring that power to them. And in this
[04:00] video, I'm going to show you the exact
[04:01] process to do that.
[04:04] Okay, so now you understand the
[04:05] opportunity. Now I'm going to give you
[04:06] the exact Morningside method playbook in
[04:08] order to capture it. So, this is a
[04:10] three-phase process that we use at
[04:11] Morningside to take any business from
[04:14] that initial state of chaos to order and
[04:16] then ultimately to growth. So, I'm
[04:17] literally open sourcing our entire
[04:19] method here for you guys to take and use
[04:20] in whatever capacity you want to. As a
[04:22] quick disclaimer though, we typically
[04:23] run this playbook for mid-market
[04:24] companies, businesses anywhere from 50
[04:26] to 500 employees. So, if that sounds a
[04:28] bit above your pay grade, don't worry
[04:29] because the principles that I'm going to
[04:30] teach you are exactly the same when
[04:32] you're applying this whether it's a 10p
[04:33] person team or a massive enterprise. So,
[04:35] you can scale it up or down exactly as
[04:37] you need. It's it's all in there and the
[04:38] process is solid.
[04:42] The first thing we do when we're
[04:43] thinking about automating a business
[04:44] with AI is that before even building a
[04:46] single tool, we get the leadership team
[04:48] on the same page. So, you cannot
[04:49] transform business if the people at the
[04:51] top don't understand the game that we're
[04:53] playing and understand the key terms and
[04:54] terminology that we're going to be going
[04:56] through, what the opportunity is. So our
[04:57] goal here in this phase is to align the
[04:59] entire leadership team to establish a
[05:01] clear strategic vision for AI within the
[05:03] company and also to communicate both the
[05:05] opportunity and the urgency to all the
[05:07] key decision makers to make sure that
[05:08] they know what's at stake here. And so
[05:10] to do this, we'll usually run a 2-hour
[05:12] AI leadership workshop alongside a
[05:13] second workshop for employees, which
[05:15] usually happens a bit later, but we'll
[05:16] charge for this on top of our fee for a
[05:18] base AI audit. And here's a crucial
[05:19] detail from our playbook is that we
[05:21] always do this before we present our
[05:22] final recommendations on where the best
[05:24] AI opportunities are. This is because it
[05:26] frankly allows us to indoctrinate them
[05:28] with our frameworks, we get them to see
[05:29] the world the way we see it and we
[05:30] establish what a best-in-class AI
[05:32] transformation looks like. And this way
[05:34] when we present our final road map
[05:36] later, they're already bought in to the
[05:37] logic. They understand the key terms and
[05:40] it's not a surprise. It's kind of a
[05:41] natural conclusion of the strategy that
[05:43] we've already agreed on in this early
[05:44] phase. One key message that helps our
[05:46] clients to see what the end goal for
[05:47] this transformation is is what we call
[05:48] an AI first or chart where we will put
[05:50] up a traditional org chart and then
[05:52] we'll swap that out for what an AI first
[05:54] organization would look like. So they
[05:55] start to build this new vision of what
[05:57] the company could look like on top of
[05:59] what they currently understand. So I'll
[06:00] put that up on screen for you to see.
[06:01] Once leadership team is educated and
[06:03] aligned and genuinely excited for the
[06:05] change that's coming for the company, we
[06:07] can then move on to the next stage which
[06:08] is identification. The goal here is to
[06:11] understand their business better than
[06:13] they do. So we are trying to become the
[06:14] world's leading expert on how their
[06:16] company actually works including like
[06:18] the warts and all and all the ugly
[06:19] parts. So this is a multi-stage process.
[06:21] It's quite a lot of work. But first we
[06:23] start off with interviews. We'll conduct
[06:24] deep dive interviews with everyone from
[06:26] department heads down to even the
[06:28] frontline staff who are in the trenches
[06:29] every day creating value for the
[06:31] company. We actually write personalized
[06:32] interview guides for basically each
[06:34] person adapting our questions as we
[06:35] learn more and more and more about the
[06:36] organization. So it kind of changes as
[06:38] we go. And the next step is what we call
[06:40] process mapping. So this is where we
[06:41] take all of that information that came
[06:43] out of the interviews. All of these data
[06:44] points that we got and then we use that
[06:46] to map out the core workflows of the
[06:48] company visually in a tool like Figma.
[06:49] And let me tell you that this step alone
[06:51] is incredibly valuable because most
[06:53] companies have SOPs, sure, but they're
[06:55] usually gathering dust in a Google Drive
[06:57] somewhere and they're completely
[06:58] updated. So for many clients, this is
[07:00] actually the first time they've seen a
[07:01] clear and objective map of how their
[07:03] business actually operates on the
[07:05] day-to-day. And then comes the part that
[07:06] requires the real expertise, which is
[07:08] the use case identification. So our
[07:10] consultants take that process map and
[07:12] then using both their knowledge and our
[07:14] internal AI solutions database which is
[07:16] over 300 proven AI systems they start to
[07:18] pinpoint the bottlenecks in those
[07:19] process maps and they find the areas
[07:21] clogged up with things like manual data
[07:22] entry report writing and repetitive
[07:24] tasks. And this is really where the
[07:26] amateurs are separated from the experts.
[07:27] It's like how much experience have you
[07:28] got? How well do you understand AI and
[07:30] what it can do for businesses? And how
[07:32] well can you layer that on top of the
[07:33] process map you see in front of you. So,
[07:34] it's all about knowing what AI solution
[07:36] fits perfectly into solve each problem
[07:38] and kind of making sure you're leaning
[07:39] into the strengths of the technology. A
[07:41] lot of the time we see these lack of ROI
[07:43] projects coming out because they are
[07:45] trying to use AI to do things that it's
[07:46] not really super good at right now. And
[07:48] it's always best to be looking at where
[07:49] is AI in production in companies right
[07:51] now actually moving the needle and can
[07:53] we lean into those rather than looking
[07:54] for the more experimental ones which is
[07:56] in most cases what people are trying to
[07:57] do. And then finally, we have the most
[07:59] important step which is the opportunity
[08:00] grading and the validation. So my
[08:02] consultants will have identified dozens
[08:03] of different opportunities, but business
[08:05] is all about prioritization of
[08:06] resources, right? Like there's always a
[08:08] million opportunities of things you can
[08:09] do, but some opportunities are
[08:11] inherently more valuable than others.
[08:12] And some are also more difficult to
[08:14] build in order to realize that value. So
[08:16] we can plot these opportunities on what
[08:17] we call the opportunity matrix. And then
[08:19] through careful process of elimination,
[08:21] we can start to trim down to the right
[08:22] mix of what we call quick wins to get a
[08:24] return on their investment as soon as
[08:26] possible once we get into development.
[08:27] also looking at, hey, what are the big
[08:29] swings for us here that will ultimately
[08:31] become a major advantage for us in the
[08:32] market versus their competitors, but
[08:34] often require some prerequisite steps or
[08:36] just generally much more investment and
[08:38] development in order to see through. So,
[08:39] you've got the quick wins and the big
[08:40] swings. And so, it's a case of trimming
[08:42] down until you get a nice mix of both.
[08:43] But another key part of the process here
[08:44] is that we're not just doing this in a
[08:46] lab on our own in isolation, then
[08:47] present the final result. We go back
[08:49] into the business and we run multiple
[08:51] validation interviews with both
[08:52] employees and the leadership. And this
[08:54] is so so so so important because when
[08:56] you go back to the employees, they
[08:57] validate that yes, we this is really a
[08:59] painful problem. Can you please solve
[09:01] this? But the leadership validates that
[09:03] solving this problem aligns with the
[09:04] company's strategic goals. And you
[09:06] absolutely have to have both. Um you
[09:08] have to have that employee buyin or the
[09:09] tools won't get used. And without the
[09:11] leadership buyin, you're not going to
[09:12] get the budget. And so the deliverable
[09:13] from all of this work is a comprehensive
[09:16] 50 to 100page final report. Yes, it's a
[09:18] beast, but it is the master plan. It is
[09:21] their AI strategy roadmap. And it lays
[09:22] out a strategic road map for their
[09:24] entire AI implementation, blending those
[09:26] quick wins that we had before with some
[09:28] of the big gamechanging swings for them
[09:30] to hit. In the free guide that I'm going
[09:31] to be sharing with you guys at the end,
[09:32] you'll be able to get some examples of
[09:33] these key slides that we put in our
[09:35] presentations that are needed to
[09:36] communicate these kind of key
[09:38] initiatives and the overall AR road map
[09:39] that they're working towards.
[09:43] All right. So once you've delivered that
[09:45] 50 to 100 page report, you've turned the
[09:46] chaos of the company into order. The
[09:48] client is blown away by how well you
[09:50] understand the business and they've
[09:51] approved the road map. Now it's time to
[09:53] turn that order into what they really
[09:55] want, which is growth, which of course
[09:56] starts with actual development. So
[09:58] following that final report, we will
[09:59] check in with the clients. Sometimes
[10:00] they'll need a month or two to get their
[10:02] budget sorted out. Other times are like
[10:03] sweet, let's go. But here is the most
[10:05] important rule for this phase is that we
[10:07] always start with the quick wins. We are
[10:08] not going to go for the six-month
[10:10] multi-million dollar moonshot project
[10:11] first. That is a shorefire way to lose
[10:14] trust and momentum. So we always pick
[10:16] the project from the road map that is
[10:17] the perfect blend of that high impact
[10:19] and low difficulty cuz we want to get
[10:21] them that tangible ROI on our entire
[10:23] engagement including both the education,
[10:25] the consulting and now the development
[10:27] as soon as possible. And that's how you
[10:28] get into by working with someone who
[10:30] knows what they're doing. You get to
[10:32] that ROI where we're just as invested in
[10:34] making sure that this all makes sense
[10:35] for you getting you to be in that 5% who
[10:37] are really starting to see an ROI on
[10:39] just the first AI initiative that you
[10:40] actually deliver. And we see this time
[10:41] and time again when you actually run the
[10:43] numbers that a targeted and seemingly
[10:44] quite basic relative to all the stuff
[10:46] you hear about in the news. These
[10:48] relatively basic systems can provide
[10:49] hundreds of thousands of dollars in ROI
[10:51] and savings from staff time wasted on
[10:53] inefficient processes. And this is one
[10:55] of the key things that I really want you
[10:56] to all take away is that for most
[10:57] businesses, the biggest quick wins that
[10:59] can get you an ROI are in the most
[11:01] boring places. We're talking about like
[11:02] soul crushing manual data entry, endless
[11:05] document creation, or the constant let
[11:06] me just look that up for you kind of
[11:08] tasks. In these cases, we can build a
[11:10] relatively simple voice agent, a smart
[11:12] transcription feature, or an agent to
[11:14] query their internal documents and
[11:15] instantly save the team hundreds of
[11:16] hours a month. And it's these simple
[11:18] systems that deliver a massive impact
[11:20] and prove the value of what we're doing.
[11:21] And these kinds of quick wins can cost
[11:22] anywhere from 20 to $50,000 or more. But
[11:25] at this point, businesses are within
[11:27] arms length of getting their first ROI
[11:29] providing AI systems built and
[11:30] developed. But development is the
[11:32] hardest part and it's the most difficult
[11:34] to replicate this consulting side of
[11:36] things. You could kind of do it
[11:37] yourself, but at the end of the day, to
[11:38] get things built out and actually
[11:40] working in production, you need talented
[11:41] developers. Because having a team with
[11:43] enough skills and experience to be able
[11:44] to tackle new and custom AI problems
[11:46] every single time is quite rough. So, if
[11:48] you're an AI agency owner just starting
[11:50] out, your goal here is simple, to be
[11:51] able to find just one versatile AI
[11:53] developer with ideally some full stack
[11:54] experience as well. And the best place
[11:56] to find them is in communities like mine
[11:57] where people are already skilled up and
[11:59] passionate about the stuff and kind of
[12:00]
